titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Joseph Kaplan Papers, 1915-1977, in the Archives of American Art AAA.kapljose
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Claire Norman

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-12-04T15:15-0500

did.abstract: The papers of the painter, photographer, printmaker, and teacher Joseph Kaplan measure 4.5 linear feet and date from 1915-1977. The bulk of the collection consists of printed material, specifically exhibition catalogs. Also found are a large number of photographs taken of and by Kaplan. The papers also include biographical material, correspondence, personal business records, and artwork.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Joseph Kaplan papers were donated to the Archives of American Art by Marilyn Kearney in 1981.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: 307 nitrate negatives donated to the Archives of American Art with the Joseph Kaplan papers have been removed and are stored in off-site storage. Negatives were duplicated onto safety based film and only select prints were made.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was fully processed with a finding aid prepared by graduate intern Claire Norman in 2013.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Joseph Kaplan papers, 1915-1977. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Joseph Kaplan papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Joseph Kaplan (1900-1980) was a painter, printmaker, photographer, and teacher who worked primarly in New York and Provincetown. He was most active in the 1940s through the 1950s. Earlier in his career he worked on several WPA Federal Art Projects and Treasury Relief Art Projects.
Joseph Kaplan was born in Minsk, Russia and immigrated with his family to the United States in 1888 at the age of 12. He married Virginia Haber in 1927 and they had no children.

Kaplan studied at the Eductional Alliance Art School and the Art Students League. He went to Provincetown in the mid-twenties as a student of Charles W. Hawthorne with whom he previously studied with at the National Academy of Design. Afterwards he revisited Provincetown intermittently and began to regard the Cape as his summer studio, working there each summer since 1948.

In 1948 he won the first of many gold medals from the Audubon Artists at the National Academy of Design for a marine painting. He was also the first recipient of the John J. Newman Memorial Medal, given by the National Society of Painters in Casein for his Wellfleet, Low Tide. The Shore Studios in Provincetown, the Harry Salpeter Gallery and then Krasner Gallery in New York City represented Kaplan's artwork.

Kaplan predominantly worked in watercolor and oil paint, depicting landscapes and seascapes, and becoming acclaimed as a Colorist and Romanticist. He occasionally painted figures and, as he gained recognition, he traveled extensively in search for subjects. In 1968 Kaplan recieved a grant from Chapelbrook Foundation to live and work for a year in Mexico.

Kaplan's work was included frequently in group exhibitions and he participated in more then 30 major shows in his lifetime. Throughout his career he was a member of many art organizations including Artists League of America, Audubon Artists, Provincetown Art Association, and Cape Cod Art Association. He was continually active in the art life in Provincetown serving as board members, trustees, and judges. He also occasionally taught at art schools including the American Artist School and John Reed Club, and taught a number of private pupils.
Joseph Kaplan died on February 28th, 1980 at the age of 79 in Brewster, Massachusetts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of the painter, photographer, printmaker, and teacher Joseph Kaplan measure 4.5 linear feet and date from 1915-1977. The bulk of the collection consists of printed material, specifically exhibition catalogs. Also found are a large number of photographs taken of and by Kaplan. The papers also include biographical material, correspondence, personal business records, and artwork.
Biographical material contains a few of Kaplan's personal documents, a number of certificates and medals he recieved during his lifetime, a travel itinerary notebook, and a few hand-written notes.

Kaplan's correspondence is primarily from colleagues, art organizations, galleries, museums, and colleges and universities such as the Corcoran Gallery of Art, National Academy of Design, and Audubon Artists, inc. Also found are letters from friends and colleagues such as Chaim Gross, Adolph Gottlieb, Raphael Soyer, Louis Lozowick, Milton Avery, and Sol Wilson, as well as a large number of letters to his wife Virginia written during his travels.

Personal business records concern Kaplan's art sales, loans, exhibition notifications, and his involvment in the WPA. His artwork is documented in price lists and inventory lists. Some of the material consists of routine transactions not necessarily related to Kaplan's work, including bank records, an address list, and income and expense reports.

Printed Material includes news clippings, exhibition catalogs, exhibition annoucenments, and invitations for Kaplan shows. There are a few published copies and page proofs of Kaplan's commerical artwork.
Artwork includes four Kaplan etchings, three of which are metal plates and one linoleum block. Also included are a few unidentified pen and pencil sketches.

Photographs depict Kaplan, mainly later in his life, and his family. Also found are four of Virginia Kaplan's photograph albums containing images of her and friends from early adulthood. Photographs of Kaplan's friends and colleagues include images of Aya and Eitaro Ishigaki, Chaim Gross, Raphael Soyer, William Gropper, and Joseph De Martini. Also included are photographs taken by Kaplan of New York City, his travels, and artist demonstrations. There are also a large number of photographs of Kaplan's artwork.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into 6 series:

list.item: Series 1: Biographical Material, 1919-1975 (Box 1, 5, OV 7; 0.3 linear feet)
Series 3: Personal Business Records, circa 1920-1977 (Box 1; 0.2 linear feet)
Series 4: Printed Material, 1915-1975 (Box 1, 2, 3, OV 7; 2.3 linear feet)
Series 6: Photographic Material, 1917-circa 1975 (Box 4, 6, OV 7; 1.3 linear feet)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Included are various certificates and medals received by Kaplan over the course of his career. Also found are a few teaching files and miscellaneous documents including a notebook containing a travel itinerary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in OV 7.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material from Box 1, Folder 2.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged into 4 subseries.

Correspondence with friends and colleagues has been arrange chronologically. Lettes from individuals who had correspondence with Kaplan of three letters or less are found within the "Friends and Colleagues" folders. Correspondence with galleries, museums, and associations has been arranged alphabetically. Letters from individuals who had correspondence with Kaplan of three letters or less are found within the "Galleries, Museums, and Associations" folders.

list.item: 2.2 Correspondence with Friends and Colleagues, circa 1930-1975
2.3 Correspondence with Galleries, Museums, and Associations, 1932-1977

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists mainly of incoming letters. A smaller amount of replies and outgoing letters are included.

The majority of the family correspondence is from Kaplan to his wife Virginia while he was traveling in 1957 and 1960. Also found is a letter written upon Kaplan's death to Virginia. The remaining family letters are from Abraham Kaplan and Helen Tumin. A few of the letters from Abraham Kaplan are in Yiddish.

Correspondence from universities and colleges, galleries, museums, and other art organizations and institutions documents Kaplan's business affairs. Letters discuss exhibitions, loans and sales of artwork, and the Works Progress Administration.

Correspondence with friends and colleagues include Aya Ishigaki, Sol Wilson, Louis Lozowick, Adolph Gottlieb, Chaim Gross, and Raphael Soyer. These letters document news of friends and activities and political organizations of interest to Kaplan.
The majority of the christmas and greeting cards are undated but include cards from Milton Avery, Chaim Gross, Aya Ishigaki, and Sol and Dora Wilson. Many of the cards are illustrated.

did.unittitle: Correspondence with Galleries, Museums, and Associations
College of Fine Arts and Applied Arts University of Illinois
Department of Information, The Federal Art Project
Federal Support for the Visual Arts: The New Deal and Now

scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in OV 7.

did.unittitle: Oversized Illustrated Greeting from Lerner Family

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material from Box 1, Folder 42.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Kaplan's art-related financial material includes WPA records, a list of artwork, price lists, loan and sale records, and exhibition notification cards. Some of the series consists of routine transactions not necessarily related to Kaplan's work including bank records, an address list, and income and expense reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed Material includes exhibition catalogs for Kaplan exhibitions dating from 1924-1971. A large portion of this series also consists of newspaper clippings and a few magazine clippings documenting exclusively Kaplan's exhibitions. Also found are magazines and copies of his commercial artwork, exhibition announcements and publications.

did.unittitle: Reprint from New York Sun and New York Herald
Program for James Joyce's Ulysses in Nighttown
Oversized Commerical Artwork by Kaplan, Page Proofs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material from Box 3, Folder 21.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artwork includes four etchings by Kaplan, three of which are metal plates and one a linoleum block. Also included are a few undated pencil and pen sketches on the back of exhibition material by an unidentified artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here are personal photographs, photographs taken by Kaplan, photographs of artwork, and miscellaneous photographs. Personal photographs depict mostly family and friends. Portraits of friends include Eitaro and Aya Ishigaki, Chaim Gross, Raphael Soyer, William Gropper, and Joseph De Martini. There is a large amount of unidentified and undated photogarphs of couples and groups, men, women, and children. Photographs taken by Kaplan include artists demonstrations in the 30s, New York City, family, friends, and travel slides of Haiti, Trindad, Mexico, Captiva, and Sanibel.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in 3 subseries

did.unittitle: Slides of Family, Friends, and Cats
